reviewText:
Before you walk past this game because it's a text adventure and doesn't offer all the fancy graphics you seek...

Let me speak some wise words of wisdom that might give you a 'permanent INT+3'  :-)

Your imagination is far more powerful and much better, more vivid, and much more fascinating then the best graphics that can be made even twenty years from today on the most powerful computer.  Your mind.  ..Don't take it for granted!

And a game like this can open up your all powerful imagination.  It has good writing and descriptive words that can spark pictures in your mind that no graphical game can possibly match.

Take a look!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mHMZfYyrqaM


..Two enthusiastic thumbs up!

reviewText: This is really good interactive fiction. I can heartily recommend it to any fans of the genre and horror in general. The writing is superb and the whole atmosphere is very engaging: grim and macabre but it's varied enough not to take away my desire to explore.\nI liked the story, and the enviroment. The artworks are not the best, but they fit the theme and the game so perfectly, that it doesn't really matter. It does get a little repetitive a few times if you die and need to redo something, and the fights feel boring and unnecesary, but those are just minor annoyances.

reviewText:
This game is baisically a hyper text choose your own adventure, if that means anything to you.

If that doesn't mean anything to you: this game is 90% text screens and clicking on text. If you are expecting lots of RPG elements and pixel art, you will be disapointed. If you don't like reading your games, you will be disapointed.

If you expect to read some atmospheric prose and chose how to die in a dungeon, you will not be disapointed. It's really pretty decent. I got it from a bundle, and you should too.

reviewText:
PROS:
*Decent writing
*Interesting environments

NEUTRAL:
*The white background, which is the vast majority of the screen, is blinding.  I got a headache while playing this game, but not everyone will have my problem, so I won't count it against the game in my review.

CONS:
*No music or sound effects
*No saving
*No skipping text that has already been seen
*Short
*Pointless combat
*No way to know if a choice will lead to death in most cases
*Writing is mostly descriptions of the player's current location or deaths
*Can't return to the main menu except after death

GAME LENGTH:
30 minutes to 2 hours.  I took around 80 minutes because I was unlucky enough to choose multiple routes that led to my death, forcing me to play the game again and again.

SCORE:
2 out of 10

Considered simply as a story, This Book Is a Dungeon is not great.  Most of the text is devoted to describing the player's current location and there doesn't seem to be much of a plot or connection among the four chapters.  The protagonist simply moves along in confusion to the next set piece, dying almost randomly.  There is not only little meaning to the meager story, but also little sense in the deaths that the protagonist endures, which also force the reader to start from the beginning of the story every time.

Considered as a game, This Book Is a Dungeon is even worse.

One notices right away that there are no sound effects or music, which are powerful and important tools for creating the appropriate atmosphere in any medium that is not restricted to visuals (or even just text) alone.  Since the text itself does only a mediocre job of creating a good atmosphere in a genre where that is usually very important (horror), there is a distinct lack of immersion.

The gameplay" consists entirely of clicking on blue text to progress
date: which is acceptable for the genre as long as it is used appropriately.  Unfortunately
recommended: the developer thought it worthwhile to try to include unavoidable
voteText: the player will enter into battle with some eldritch horror and be forced to click on the same blue text repeatedly as the character and monster whittle away at each other's health by 1 or 2 HP at a time
helpfulPercent: the process of which is extended by their mutual inaccuracy.  The player here is merely an observer.  Though I never died in battle against one of these creatures
votesTotal: so I am forced to conclude that they are just one of many examples of unfair deaths that
commentsCount: require the player to start from the beginning of the game.\n\nI would mention other such deaths
column16: but they would constitute the only real spoilers for the game besides the meaningless ending.  Trust me when I say that there is generally no way to know what will happen after any given choice nor any way to prepare for the consequences.\n\nBeing forced to play through the game again after each death because there is no save feature even within a chapter is bad enough.  But the absence of a skip button
column17: the delays between text that progresses the story
column18: and particularly one chapter where I estimate that the player must get through over 80 separate lines of text before he can make any choice make the game much more frustrating.\n\nFor me
column19: this was not a game in which surviving a chapter created a sense of accomplishment.  It was a game in which knowing that more senseless deaths and clicking awaited me created a sense of dread--and not of a Lovecraftian nature.  The ending
column21: did nothing to help me feel that my experience was worthwhile.\n\nAnd while I was ultimately grateful to only spend 80 minutes on the game
column22: the roughly 30 minutes of actual content does not justify the $6 price tag of a text-based game.\n\nThe developer has expressed a desire to improve the combat and include sound and achievements
column23: but says that the game engine makes these features difficult or impossible.  That is not an excuse; it is a reason to not use the engine in the first place.  And it certainly does not excuse the tedium that the player must endure after each death.\n\nAs I find that This Book Is a Dungeon fails both as a story and a game
column24: but recognize that the writing is of decent quality and the environments are interesting
column25: I give it a 2 out of 10."

reviewText: This choose-your-own-adventure style Lovecraftian horror game is light on combat and puzzles but heavy on amazing storytelling and blood curdling imagery (via text).  The pixel art is spread out but top notch.  It is a huge throwback to older adventure games (Zork Zero comes to mind) I liked to play... but more accessable.\n\nThe game has a ton of amazing detail work and is a true work of art.  The developer is still ironing our a few typos but all-in-all I am having a great time exploring all the awful ways to perish in this dark and cruel world he built. A+!

reviewText: The format of this game is great, a style of game i've always wished for but never found. The story is brilliantly Lovecraftian and engrossing, particullary the work that went into the collections of books and tomes in the library section. My only qualms are that firstly the fact that you had to complete each painting in sequence without any form of checkpoint, is very frustrating, and I think it was to the detriment of the imersive story, as it required me to repeat sections by flashing through the choices to finish it. Secondly the one piece of combat in the game seemed absolutely arbitrary as it was seemingly unfailable, would of loved to of seen better use of a combat system or for it to be left out completely, or solely conducted through choice and consequence, as with the Avian creature in the first dungeon. Alltogether though I enjoyed this game and I would love to see a sequel as well as other creators making this kind of game.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you enjoy lovingly-crafted, twisted and macabre descriptions of your own death, this is the game for you.

A text-based Choose-Your-Own-Adventure with occasional illustrations, this game excels in its writing and atmosphere (which variously play with Lovecraftian, psychological and body horror).

However, you will die a lot. And while your deaths will be creative, and described in oh so much detail, every death means having all your progress reset. Since the chapters are largely linear in structure (though you can attempt them in any order), and most puzzles have only one solution, you will find yourself retreading familiar ground over and over again with increasing frustration. This also disincentivises experimentation - many times it will be clear to a genre-savvy player that a certain option will lead to an interesting, well-written and horrible death, but you won't want to try it out due to the hefty progress penalty involved (there is, of course, no saving).

With that said, a complete playthrough (which, sadly, involves going through the exact same thing multiple times if you want all the endings) will last you a few hours at most, If that's an investment you're prepared to make in the name of some well-written horror, then I would definitely recommend this game, especially given its low price.

reviewText: It was a nice read, but its just too short. It could be finished in a half hour if it didn't reset back to the start with every loss. Resetting so far is a real loss, its hard to be engrossed when you spend a minute or two clicking through pages you had already read, some of which move at their own dramatic pace. Its something you would probably find interesting and appreciate when its free on a site, but if you plan to buy it I would wait until its a price your willing to pay for an hour or less of your time.

reviewText: A well made Twine game is an amazing experience, and this is very well made. The writing is solid, and the dev really pushed the limits on what Twine can do, adding things like combat, an inventory, and a map to the usual text-based navigation, which is especially impressive given it's his first time using Twine, and was made in only three months. Combined with the developer's diary, this isn't just a game, it's inspiration for anyone who's ever wanted to take a shot at making their own.\nBetween this and Go To Bed, the first game from his studio Touchfight Games, Nathan Meunier has made the very short list of indie developers who I'll play everything they make - joining Freebird Games (To The Moon and A Bird Story) and David Szymanski (Fingerbones, The Moon Sliver, The Music Machine, and A Wolf in Autumn).

reviewText:
It's a good game for the few fans of the genre. It's a horror text-based game, so don't expect anything else than having to read a lot to advance in this game.

I didn't like this game that much, but it obviously has some good points. By not having a lot a visual content, it makes you imagine the action, and this works very well for this game. The author writes pretty well, so it's easy to read and to imagine what's going on.

Also, don't imagine to go in this dungeon and survive on the first go; that won't happen. You will die more time than you can remember. But this is the way that this game is supposed to be played: you will die in very differents ways and the descriptions make it fun to die. Really. It's not frustrating to die, at least, not in this game.

The negative side of dying a lot is to have to start from one of the few points you can start from and having to pass through the same text again... and again.

So if you know what this game is about and it appeals to you, give it a go. But don't expect to play it for long, it's a very short, but entertaining game.

I don't feel the gamebook is quite worth the full asking price considering the length and the lack of audio ambience but it's certainly not a bad piece of work at all and anyone who loves otherwordly horror shouldn't be too disappointed at the variety of horrible ways one can end the adventure.  Certainly pick it up if you find it on sale

reviewText:
I cut my teeth on text adventure games back when they were in their heyday, on a Vic20 with a 24K RAM expander just so they would load from the cassette.

Around that time the Choose Your Own Adventure books became popular in my elementary school as well, and I think I read them all.

TWINE fiction is a new genre for me, and as an introduction 'This Book Is A Dungeon' is a stellar production. Atmospheric, twisted, and fiendish in all the ways it seeks to kill you.

I do wish it was longer, but I've been replaying to see the various ways I can meet my end. Give it a try and see what horrible fate awaits you.

reviewText: This game has offered one of the most eerie, surreal, nightmarish and unnerving sensations given to me by any game or horror writing. It's done greater than most works of Lovecraft or King I've read. It's a kind of nervious, anxious uncertainty of every action's consequence and result mixed with the lack of sound and hand-holding that leaves you hanging on every last word as if they could be the last you read if you make the wrong move.\n\nI spent a good long while in this game in an introspective hallucination where everytime I put my ear to one side of the four walls of the room I felt like I journeyed or was taken somewhere or felt and heard things that clearly weren't there in reality or in the game. It offered a terrifyingly vivid feeling of immersion that leaves me a bit scared and a bit excited and enthralled. Quite possibly one of the most unusual and amazing experiences I've ever had with a game or literature. Interative Literature if you rather.

reviewText: A rather unnerving choose your own adventure dealing with Lovecraftian themes. The writing is excellent and accompanied by creepy pixel art of monsters and other horrible beings. Story is well done and branches off into different paths that either lead to success or a plethora of really detailed deaths.... Combat is medioce and probably should not have been included. Additionally, since large segements of text cannot be skipped, playthoughs to discover alternative paths can get really tedious.

reviewText:
Note: I won a free copy of the game through a contest held by the creator (I believe).

Overall, this is an enjoyable and unique game. The story was fun, the writing was good, and it had a creepy atmosphere throughout. I especially liked the crude pixelart drawings and scenery that would pop up every so often, it really added to the text.

A lot of people are describing this game as a choose your own adventure"
date: but I would disagree. This is a puzzle game that just happens to be text-based. While there are choices
recommended: in my playthrough I didn't find they had a long-lasting impact like they would in a choose-your-own adventure book. They mostly altered the short-term
voteText: or were cosmetic (with the exception of the ending
helpfulPercent:
which seemed to come out of nowhere which was a bit disappointing).

Some things that may turn some people off from this game:

- It's very short. I beat it with a friend in just under two hours even though I had to redo a section about three or four times. There are about five "chapters" to the book and it ends rather abruptly.

- There's no real "save" feature
votesHelpful: just one or two major milestones you can restart at. This was a bit frustrating because death can be very punishing when you're caught unaware. The first time I died I was set back two chapters (about 30 minutes worth of game). A save feature or at least chapter checkpoints would be nice.\n\n- The game is surprisingly easy. Maybe I just got lucky
votesTotal: but there were only two parts I "lost" at. There were also no points in the game I got "stuck" not knowing what to do.\n\n- A few sections of the game had a very crude combat system that amounted to nothing more than luck and clicking "attack" over and over until the fight ended. There weren't many of these fights (only one or two depending on your choices) but I felt they detracted from the game. I'm all for a combat system
votesFunny: but the way it's currently implemented isn't fun since there's absolutely no strategy that I could discern.\n\n- While the writing is great the story is a bit weak. Things happen but there's no real reason for them. The game doesn't need to explain everything that exists in its world
commentsCount: but considering it sells itself as a book it would've been nice for the story to be a bit more fleshed out.\n\nUltimately
column16: this was a fun game that harkens back to old horror/text based adventure games (and does it better than I've seen in recent years). Should you buy it? Well
column17: if text-based horror is your thing then this is a very nice title. For me personally the price does seem a bit high considering the amount of content in the game but if even a couple more chapters were added and some of the issues I described above were improved then this could be a real gem."

2. The pictures and map need to be much bigger. I think that this may be a limitation of twine maybe?
3. A few more resart points would be nice. I had to replay the three pictures many times and it turns into rapid clicking just to get to the point I was at.

One last thing, please make a sequal. Im off to look up twine to see if I can make my own dungeon.

reviewText:
This game is a wonderfully dark text-adventure game with detailed grim descriptions and great pixel art. I played through it a couple times and it took me about two hours to read through everything and solve the puzzles, but after you know what you're doing you can breeze through it.

There is only one thing I don't like about the game: there is one random encounter in the game, just one. It doesn't really fit the rest of the point and click style. The combat isn't even fleshed out either, all it amounts to is clicking attack until you or the monster drops dead and it drags on just a little too long. I don't mind it since it's the only encounter in the game, but I would prefer that either there were more encounters with a little more substance, or just remove it completely.

All in all the game is a great way to spend a couple hours if you're looking for a good story

reviewText:
Cute, small indie game.
Good storytelling that developes a curiosity and a creepy atmosphere.
It took me about 2 and a half to three hours  to get AN ending ( I've heard there are alot more than one )
but i need to investigate further....
People say this game is too short, but I dont think that's true to be frank, It's more than long enough.
Bought this game on halloween sale, definitely would play it again to get all the secrets and results.
Well made, Very good storytelling that keeps you on your toes and worth buying.

reviewText: Down to the point, this is an interesting and neat game. However, I can see that this game is mearly the start of a larger project or it is simply the basics for more content related to the game. It's generally short for a game but it completely makes up for that with it's sense of style and the immersion within the game. The game does have its shortcomings, such as a stupidly simplistic combat scenario that was thrown in there and the fact that there are no saves to speak of, meaning that you'll have to redo everything upon death, which WILL happen. This is partially solved by being able to skip to certain main areas within the game and bypass all the tedious clicking, however. The game overall gives much more than it looks to possess and can easily be expanded on.\n\nIt's short, simple, and delivers a whole world to the player. I'd recommend buying it and waiting to see if any more related content comes out.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Note: I won a free copy of the game through a contest held by the creator (I believe).

Overall, this is an enjoyable and unique game. The story was fun, the writing was good, and it had a creepy atmosphere throughout. I especially liked the crude pixelart drawings and scenery that would pop up every so often, it really added to the text.

A lot of people are describing this game as a choose your own adventure"
date: but I would disagree. This is a puzzle game that just happens to be text-based. While there are choices
recommended: in my playthrough I didn't find they had a long-lasting impact like they would in a choose-your-own adventure book. They mostly altered the short-term
voteText: or were cosmetic (with the exception of the ending
helpfulPercent:
which seemed to come out of nowhere which was a bit disappointing).

Some things that may turn some people off from this game:

- It's very short. I beat it with a friend in just under two hours even though I had to redo a section about three or four times. There are about five "chapters" to the book and it ends rather abruptly.

- There's no real "save" feature
votesHelpful: just one or two major milestones you can restart at. This was a bit frustrating because death can be very punishing when you're caught unaware. The first time I died I was set back two chapters (about 30 minutes worth of game). A save feature or at least chapter checkpoints would be nice.\n\n- The game is surprisingly easy. Maybe I just got lucky
votesTotal: but there were only two parts I "lost" at. There were also no points in the game I got "stuck" not knowing what to do.\n\n- A few sections of the game had a very crude combat system that amounted to nothing more than luck and clicking "attack" over and over until the fight ended. There weren't many of these fights (only one or two depending on your choices) but I felt they detracted from the game. I'm all for a combat system
votesFunny: but the way it's currently implemented isn't fun since there's absolutely no strategy that I could discern.\n\n- While the writing is great the story is a bit weak. Things happen but there's no real reason for them. The game doesn't need to explain everything that exists in its world
commentsCount: but considering it sells itself as a book it would've been nice for the story to be a bit more fleshed out.\n\nUltimately
column16: this was a fun game that harkens back to old horror/text based adventure games (and does it better than I've seen in recent years). Should you buy it? Well
column17: if text-based horror is your thing then this is a very nice title. For me personally the price does seem a bit high considering the amount of content in the game but if even a couple more chapters were added and some of the issues I described above were improved then this could be a real gem."

reviewText: A rather unnerving choose your own adventure dealing with Lovecraftian themes. The writing is excellent and accompanied by creepy pixel art of monsters and other horrible beings. Story is well done and branches off into different paths that either lead to success or a plethora of really detailed deaths.... Combat is medioce and probably should not have been included. Additionally, since large segements of text cannot be skipped, playthoughs to discover alternative paths can get really tedious.

reviewText: This game has offered one of the most eerie, surreal, nightmarish and unnerving sensations given to me by any game or horror writing. It's done greater than most works of Lovecraft or King I've read. It's a kind of nervious, anxious uncertainty of every action's consequence and result mixed with the lack of sound and hand-holding that leaves you hanging on every last word as if they could be the last you read if you make the wrong move.\n\nI spent a good long while in this game in an introspective hallucination where everytime I put my ear to one side of the four walls of the room I felt like I journeyed or was taken somewhere or felt and heard things that clearly weren't there in reality or in the game. It offered a terrifyingly vivid feeling of immersion that leaves me a bit scared and a bit excited and enthralled. Quite possibly one of the most unusual and amazing experiences I've ever had with a game or literature. Interative Literature if you rather.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I had the privilege of reviewing This Book is a Dungeon for GamerHeadlines.com and got to play it a week before release; I was provided with a free copy by Nathan Meunier himself.

I really, really enjoyed this game despite its short length. That's kind of what makes it so good. It's bite-sized so you can easily replay it to find other paths and such that you missed the first time around. It's a lot of trial and error and you'll die super often, but it's worth it.

If you're interested, check out my full review here: http://www.gamerheadlines.com/reviews/this-book-is-a-dungeon/

reviewText: A short, sweet horror game, the mildlly-tedious repetition after failing kinda breaks the horror immersion, but it doesn't detract from the overall enjoyment I felt. It was a slice of perfectly dark horror with crushing hopelessness, and I enjoy it heavily. Personally, I grabbed it on sale, so the two hours it took me to do every possible thing was worth it, but it may not be like that for everyone. Pick it up on sale if you're sketchy, but buy it normally if you're in love with the concept.

reviewText:
I love this. It is so intriguing. I have this wierd hobby/addiction to psychological novels, especially if it relates to dark beliefs. Just reading about gore and blood makes me feel all warm and fuzzy inside. I am even writing my own novel called The Girl Who Stole My Soul, a psychological horror romance with themes of depression and vengance inside too. This Book Is A Dungeon did not inspire me to start writing it, but it does provide me a reference for my novel, since it describes gore and blood in a way I admire. Just writing the first chapter of The Girl Who Stole My Soul made me sweat a quart of sweat.

I suppose I am getting off topic. I haven't seen this game to its fullest, but I will soon, since I love it. Chapter 2 is by far my favorite with so many individual stories and books in the study. I was stuck on Chapter 4 for the longest time though.

By far my favorite interactive novel, one of my most favorite novels of all time. 10/10

reviewText:
This game to me, feels something between a point-and-click adventure and a text-based walking simulator (click-through simulator?) with a singe of an experience that is narrated by a dungeon master in a DnD game. A rather unforgiving point-and-click adventure. That's not saying I haven't enjoyed the almost 3 hours I've played in chapters 1, 3, and 2. But I've been left somewhat wanting.

Apart from living or dying, the choices you make don't have an impact, making it an illusion of choice, if I'm not mistaken. They seem more like puzzles, or riddles to solve through either common sense, thinking, intuition, luck, or bruteforce (as in, dying and trying again).

The latter is sometimes quite entertaining, some of your failures (that is, deaths) have deliciously elaborate flavour. Others are simply a bland sentence, which has left me feeling left out, when walking through the entry area multiple times - exploring other dialogue choices. And having to click through from the beginnign of a level or dungeon, to the points you may have died, is quite a tedium.

I would probably end up saying that the game itself is nothing special in its form or mechanics, and the only thing unique about it is the story that has been written for it. I would not describe it as a dungeon crawler in the classical meaning when it comes to computer games.

After all, I'd say that I don't know anybody I would recommend this game to.

reviewText: It is a really good text adventure game in the vein of old Infocom games like Zork with a added flair of some graphical liberties. I would compare it to those wonderful 'Choose Your Own Adventure' books I use to read as a kid; and just like those I wouldn't expect much in the way of animations or audio. It knows its strength is in the writing and that is what it focuses on. If not having audio or graphical flair is bothersome to you, then skip it. Otherwise, it is a delightful read.\n\n9/10

reviewText: Remember those choose your adventure books from yesteryears when you were able to hold a book in your hands. This is just like that, but on your PC. Blood fills the page as you start your adventure, decide what to do if you want to escape from this dungeon. Be warned that this game has no checkpoint, but two different parts to start from. You will read the story and you will be totally invested in it. After all, This Review Is A Dungeon.
